byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and JOHN SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Campbell Robertson reported from New Orleans, and John Schwartz from New York.

lead_paragraph: An article by experts involved in some previous examinations of the catastrophe contends that fault should fall squarely on the Army Corps of Engineers.

headline.print_headline: Decade After Katrina, Experts Point Finger More Firmly at the Army Corps
headline.main: Decade After Katrina, Pointing Finger More Firmly at Army Corps

snippet: An article by experts involved in some previous examinations of the catastrophe contends that fault should fall squarely on the Army Corps of Engineers.
abstract: J David Rogers study in journal Water Policy, coming decade after Hurricane Katrina caused catastrophic flooding in New Orleans, seeks to place additional blame on United States Army Corps of Engineers for failures in city's flood protection system; article comes amid for legal accountability on part of federal government restitution for those affected by Katrina's floodwaters.
